fields_of_interest: Humanitarian aid and civil protection, Budget, Culture, International co-operation and development, Education and training, Employment and Social Affairs, Youth, Justice and Fundamental Rights, Research and innovation, Public Health, Communication
eu_initiatives: we are engaged into the development of the EU Action plan on Drugs, watch closely the EU HIV strategy and provide regularly input into Germanys national HIV/ STI strategy, currently we are commenting on the so-called Marshallplan with Africa developed by our ministry BMZ . Our focus has always been beyond national boundaries as our engagement in GFAN, UNAIDS and ECDC - structures demonstrate. We were members of the CSF some years ago. We will continue our work in national and European networks and give input in CSFs work from our work, our member organisations work and the discussions in other networks were are involved in. We intent to give ourselves a multiplying role between the CSFs advocacy efforts and our member organisations. By doing so we intent to contribute to CSFs work as well as to our advocacy efforts at national level. Our topics and work always has a European dimension, nevertheless this aspects often are neglected in debates – in the wider public as well as in civil society. We want to promote the European dimension in debates on health. For this, we want to build wider networks and connect our member organisations with other European civil society organisations. In the past, we often experienced the great importance of support from other European organisations in advocacy efforts at national level. As a member of CSF, we want to contribute to a well-networked civil society at European level promoting from local to European level.
subsection: Non-governmental organisations, platforms and networks and similar

some of our staff members are members (engaged with):  
 
- EU CSF on Drugs 
- EATG (European AIDS Treatment Group) 
- EPHA (European Public Health Alliance) 
- HIPP (WHO Health in Prison Project)
goals__remit:
Action against AIDS Germany is a nationwide network of about 300 groups and organizations. These include local AIDS-aid groups, Protestant and Catholic churches and communities, one-world shops as well as organizations working in the field of development cooperation, humanitarian aid, HIV & AIDS, and health issues. As a Germany-wide network, Action against AIDS advocates for the necessary attention and consistent pursuit of the aim of an end of AIDS by 2030.  
We inform and sensitize the wider public as well as decision-makers through talks, conferences, publications, press-work, campaigns and actions. The aim is to improve the situation of disadvantaged people who are at risk or particularly affected by HIV and AIDS. The promotion as access to treatment and care is one of our main priorities.  
 
We address policy makers in the German Parliament and the Federal Government, because they are the center-point for decisions both on financial efforts to tackle HIV and health promotion as well as on national and international agreements. It is important to us that effective prevention and access to affordable medicines and diagnostics become a reality globally. Main target of activities relate to advocacy and awareness raising of the situation of disadvantaged populations in Germany and MIC and LIC of the global south, the responsibility our Government has to contribute a fair share to a fully funded Global Fund to fight against the AIDS, TB and Malaria and other neglected diseases.  
 
We urge the federal government to fulfill the commitment of providing 0.7% of gross national income (GNI) to development co-operation and (included) 0.1% of GNI to measures that promote Global Health. This also implies that the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria (www.theglobalfund.org) is adequately funded. 
The key risk groups affected by the disease vary from region to region, in our country key populations are gay men, PUD, migrants, mobile populations and prisoners. We advocate for their rights and access to treatment and prevention through our networks and by active participation through our partners from, for example, MSF in panels like the EU CSF on Drugs, the GFAN Network, the UNAIDS PCP meetings (as part of the community from the country delegation) or the ECDC expert panel on prison health
relevant_communication: Main advocacy activities relate to a fair contribution the replenishment conference for the Global Fund to fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. Together with organisations from the AgA-network and cooperation partners, we hold an “action week” prior to the replenishment meeting to promote our call for Germany’s fair contribution to a fully funded Global Fund. The action week was given good media coverage. Beside these activities, we participated as part of the community and country delegation at the UN High Level Meeting on HIV, commented on the declaration and communicated the results focusing on the lack of integration of vulnerable groups and Civil Society. In autumn, we had a couple of parliamentarian events including one on drug pricing using the example of Hepatitis C drugs – an event organized in collaboration with MdM, MSF and other partners. During the summer, we published the 130-page report “Fifth Edition of the Civil Society Appraisal of the Political and Financial Contributions provided by the German Government in support of the UN Targets on Global Health and HIV Control”.  We participated in the UNAIDS PCP meeting, were invited to participate the EU CSF on drugs, provided input for the new EU strategy on drugs and provided input for the ECDC expert panel on prison health (were access to HCV dugs, TB treatment and access to harm reduction services for prisoners were addressed).  We are in constant contact with the Federal Ministry of Health and the German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development and provide on a regular basis input into strategies, such as the National HIV, STI and Hepatitis Strategy, the “Roadmap Healthy systems-Healthy Lives” or currently the “Marshall Plan for Africa”. As every year we participated in the church days and hold the “solidarity night”.
